title: The 3th conference of Monitoring, Early Warning, and Scientific Management of Vegetation Pests and Diseases
text:
The 3rd Conference on Remote Sensing of Vegetation Pests and Diseases will be hosted from 9:00 am to 5:30 pm, on August 27-28, 2022 (Beijing Time), themed “Protecting Plants and Safeguarding Security” and jointly organized by the Aerospace Information Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Anhui University, Manchester Metropolitan University, China Biodiversity Conservation and Green Development Foundation, Chinese Society of Agricultural Engineering, Hangzhou Dianzi University, National Engineering Research Center for Agro-Ecological Big Data Analysis & Application, etc.





To facilitate the in-depth applications of remote sensing technology in intelligent plant protection, disaster monitoring and forecasting, ecological security, etc., the cross-disciplinary integration and technology innovations of monitoring, early warning, and prevention and control of vegetation pests and diseases will be fully investigated. It is to promote the theoretical innovations and industrial applications of remote sensing of vegetation pests and diseases, and to build an ecological civilization, pursue the harmonious coexistence of man and nature and build a community of all life on Earth.
The conference will gather scientists from various fields such as remote sensing, plant protection, ecology, environment, meteorology, artificial intelligence, ethics of science and technology, etc. It focuses on the biodiversity protection, green prevention and control of pests and diseases, ecological security assessment of agriculture, forestry, prataculture, etc. The latest scientific achievements and future development trend of theories, models, methods, systems and applications will be deeply explored concerning the remote sensing based key applications of monitoring, early warning, prevention and control of vegetation pests and diseases.
One of the key objectives of the conference is to facilitate cross-disciplinary and industry-academia-research-application integration, and to promote the theoretical research, methodology innovation, technology extension and application demonstration of remote sensing in the field of vegetation pests and diseases. The domestic and international experts and scholars involved in the remote sensing-based studies on vegetation pests and diseases will be invited to present the academic reports during the conference.

27-28 August 2022

title: Kaggle competition 2023: Beyond Visible Spectrum: AI for Agriculture
text:
To facilitate the global collaboration across a wide range of communities and promote development of novel AI-enabled applications in agriculture, forestry and grassland, addressing food security and sustainability, we will continue hold the second kaggle competition that consists of two parts including 1) Automated Crop Disease Diagnosis from Hyperspectral Imagery; 2) Boosting automatic crop type classification using Sentinel satellite data and self-supervised learning.


Early accurate diagnosis and quantification of crop diseases are crucial for precision management by allowing targeted interventions at the field level. Effective diagnosis and control measures are dependent on symptom recognition and severity assessment (in the vast majority of cases, diseases exhibit a range of visual symptoms, e.g. coloured spots or streaks). At present, these are mainly achieved by visual observation and estimation.
Recent advancements in digital imaging have facilitated the development of a variety of image-based methods for plant management that are capable of performing automated image acquisition and analysis. These methods have shown great potential for automated crop disease diagnosis based on images from RGB (red, green and blue), thermal, multispectral, and hyperspectral sensors.
Particularly, hyperspectral imagery (HSI), which contains more narrow spectral bands over a contiguous spectral range, provides detailed spectral–spatial information of the disease infestation and offers the potential to provide better diagnostic accuracy.
In this challenge, we will provide a hyperspectral image dataset of wheat fields with yellow rust disease. We mainly focus on the accurate diagnosis of crop diseases from hyperspectral imagery (in this case, yellow rust disease). The benchmark model for this competition is based on our published paper on remote sensing [1].
1. A Deep Learning-Based Approach for Automated Yellow Rust Disease Detection from High-Resolution Hyperspectral UAV Images




The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) estimates that current agricultural production needs to grow by up to 70 percent by 2050 in order to meet the expected population growth on Earth. This poses a significant challenge for food production, which requires solutions that not only enhance agricultural methods but also adapt them radically to environmental pressures. Big data, machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI) have the potential to play a vital role in this process.
The crop type classification is an important part of agriculture as an industry. Remote sensing data offers large scale, long term, continuous monitoring on the ground and has long been used as an extremely useful tool for crop classification. Identifying crops using traditional supervised learning methods can be a challenging task, as obtaining a large number of ground-truthing training samples is often a time-consuming and laborious work.
In recent years, there has been a new research trend to train models without using labels, named Self-supervised learning (SSL). It has been effectively applied in many fields such as computer vision, natural language processing, and object detection. In fact, by extracting representative features from unlabelled data, the SSL algorithm has outperformed supervised pre-training on many problems. In this respect, self-supervised learning is a promising avenue for remote sensing research.
In this challenge, we will release a massive remote sensing dataset in cropland area, including multispectral and SAR data for participants to train their self-supervised learning models. A crop classification task will be set up to evaluate the effectiveness of their SSL model.

Participation instructions

Workshop/conference
This challenge is part of the conference on “The third conference of Monitoring, Early Warning, and Scientific Management of Vegetation Pests and Diseases” in Aug 2022.
